# Stream editing functions



## sed_insert

<h3>Insert one or more lines</h3>


<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>sed_insert(stream, after, insertion, warn = FALSE, ...)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>stream</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector, each element typically (but not necessarily) containing the text
from a single line in a file, which can be generated via <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>after</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">An integer or character string that designates where <code>insertion</code> is added to <code>stream</code>.
If <code>after</code> is numeric, it designates the line (or element) number in <code>stream</code> after which the
<code>insertion</code> will be placed. The numeric value of <code>after</code> must be in <code>[0:length(stream)]</code>.
To make an insertion at the very beginning of <code>stream</code>, use <code>after = 0</code>.  If <code>after</code> is a
character string, the insertion is placed after the first element in <code>stream</code> that contains the string,
where matching is obtained using <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>insertion</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector that will be inserted into the stream after element <code>after</code>.
Each element in the vector would correspond to a separate line in the file.</dd>
  <dt>warn</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">If <code>TRUE</code>, warning messages are produced if insertion fails due to mispecifification
of <code>after</code>.</dd>
  <dt>...</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">Additional named arguments to <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code>, which are applicable if <code>after</code> is a character string.
In other words, <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code> is used to search for the first instance of <code>after</code>.</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Details</h4>

  <p class="rd-p"><code>sed_insert</code> only accomodates a single insertion point.  Multiple lines may be inserted, but only one
insertion point is allowed, which is why <code>length(insertion)</code> must be 1.  To make insertions at multiple locations,
<code>sed_insert</code> can be called repeatedly on the same string as needed.</p>


  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">The new <code>stream</code> with the insertions added. If the insertion fails because <code>after</code> is
specified incorrectly, <code>stream</code> is returned unchanged.</p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>################################################################################
# Let's create an example stream we can edit
################################################################################
stream <- c("Here's a line",
           "And another line",
           "Line after which we'll insert a string",
           "A line after which we'll insert another string",
           "A final line")
as.stream(stream)

# Insert a string using line numbers
stream <- sed_insert(stream, after = 3, "Here's the first insertion")
stream

# Insert a stream by searching for a string
stream <- sed_insert(stream,
                    c("Here's the second insertion",
                      "",
                      "Another line of the second insertion after the blank line"),
                    after = "insert another")
stream</code></pre>

<h4>See also</h4>

<code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code>, <code><a href=#streamedit>streamEdit</a></code>


<h4>Author</h4>

Landon Sego




## sed_replace

<h3>Delete or replace an entire line</h3>


<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>sed_replace(stream, at, replacement, warn = FALSE, ...)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>stream</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector, each element typically (but not necessarily) containing the text
from a single line in a file, which can be generated via <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>at</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A vector of integers or a character string that designates where <code>replacement</code>
is placed in <code>stream</code>.  If <code>at</code> is numeric, it designates the lines (or elements) in <code>stream</code>
that will be replaced with <code>replacement</code>.  The numeric value(s) of <code>at</code> must be in
<code>[1:length(stream)]</code>. If <code>at</code> is a
character string, the lines in <code>stream</code> that contain the string <code>at</code> are replaced with
<code>replacement</code>.</dd>
  <dt>replacement</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string of length 1 (vectors not supported), that will be inserted
to replace the entire line. Or, if <code>replacement = NULL</code>, the entire line
is deleted.</dd>
  <dt>warn</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">If <code>TRUE</code>, warning messages are produced if replacement fails due to mispecifification
of <code>at</code>.</dd>
  <dt>...</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">Additional named arguments to <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code>, which are applicable if <code>at</code> is a character string.
In other words, <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code> is used to search for the instances of <code>at</code>.</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">The new <code>stream</code> with the replacements. If the replacement fails because <code>after</code> is
specified incorrectly, <code>stream</code> is returned unchanged.</p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>################################################################################
# Let's create an example stream we can edit
################################################################################
stream <- c("Here's a line",
           "Here's a line we'll delete",
           "Filler line",
           "A line we'll delete",
           "A line we'll entirely replace",
           "The last line")
as.stream(stream)

# Here's a deletion of lines 1 and 2 using line numbers
stream <- sed_replace(stream, 1:2, NULL)
stream

# Here's a line deletion using a search string
stream <- sed_replace(stream, "A line we'll delete", NULL)
stream

# A line replacement using line numbers
stream <- sed_replace(stream, 2, "A new filler line")
stream

# Here's a line replacement with a search string
stream <- sed_replace(stream, "entirely", "A replacement for the line")
stream

# And we can replace multiple lines too
stream <- sed_replace(stream, "line", "All the same")
stream</code></pre>

<h4>See also</h4>

<code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code>, <code><a href=#streamedit>streamEdit</a></code>


<h4>Author</h4>

Landon Sego




## sed_substitute

<h3>Substitute one string for another</h3>


<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>sed_substitute(stream, pattern, replacement, every = TRUE, warn = FALSE,
  ...)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>stream</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector, each element typically (but not necessarily) containing the text
from a single line in a file, which can be generated via <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>pattern</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string containing the regular expression that will be used to identify
which the elements (or lines) in <code>stream</code> that will be substituted using <code>sed_substitute</code>.</dd>
  <dt>replacement</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string of length 1 (vectors not supported), that will be substituted
for the <code>pattern</code>.  Setting <code>replacement = ""</code> will remove the characters matched
to <code>pattern</code>.</dd>
  <dt>every</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A logical indicating whether every instance of <code>pattern</code> in each line should be
substituted with <code>replacement</code>, in which case <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>gsub</a></code> is used.
If <code>every = FALSE</code>, only the first instance of <code>pattern</code> in each line is substituted, in which case
<code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>sub</a></code> is used.</dd>
  <dt>warn</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">If <code>TRUE</code>, warning messages are produced if substitution fails due to mispecifification
of <code>pattern</code>.</dd>
  <dt>...</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">Additional named arguments to <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grepl</a></code> and <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>gsub</a></code> or <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>sub</a></code>.  <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grepl</a></code>
is used to verify whether <code>pattern</code> is present in <code>stream</code>.  <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>gsub</a></code> or <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>sub</a></code> are used
to perform the substitution, depending on the value of <code>every</code>.</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">The new <code>stream</code> with the substitions. If the substitution fails because <code>pattern</code> is not found,
<code>stream</code> is returned unchanged.</p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>################################################################################
# Let's create an example stream we can edit
################################################################################
stream <- c("Here's a line",
           "A line where we'll make a substitution",
           "A line where we'll delete 'this'",
           "Several nonsense nonsense repeated strings nonsense",
           "Another nonsense line with nonsense repeated strings",
           "The last line")
as.stream(stream)

# Here's a deletion within the line
stream <- sed_substitute(stream, " 'this'", "")
stream

# Here's a substitution of text
stream <- sed_substitute(stream, "substitution", "correction")
stream

# Show the difference between 'every = TRUE' and 'every = FALSE'
sed_substitute(stream, " nonsense", "", every = TRUE)
sed_substitute(stream, " nonsense", "", every = FALSE)</code></pre>

<h4>See also</h4>

<code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code>, <code><a href=#streamedit>streamEdit</a></code>


<h4>Author</h4>

Landon Sego




## sed_comment

<h3>Add or remove comment characters to a line</h3>


<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>sed_comment(stream, at, add = TRUE, type = c("R", "C", "Java", "html",
  "tex", "SAS"), warn = FALSE, ...)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>stream</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector, each element typically (but not necessarily) containing the text
from a single line in a file, which can be generated via <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>at</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A vector of integers or a character string that designates the line(s) that will be commented.
If <code>at</code> is numeric, it designates the line(s) (or elements) in <code>stream</code> that will be commented.
The numeric value(s) of <code>at</code> must be in <code>[1:length(stream)]</code>. If <code>at</code> is a
character string, the line(s) in <code>stream</code> that contain the string <code>at</code> are commented.</dd>
  <dt>add</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A logical indicating whether comments are added to a single
line (<code>TRUE</code>), or removed (<code>FALSE</code>).</dd>
  <dt>type</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string uniquely indicating the programming language: R, C, Java, html, tex, and SAS.
Customized commenting can be achieved by providing a character vector of length 2, where <code>type[1]</code> designates
the beginning comment character and <code>type[2]</code> designates the ending comment character.</dd>
  <dt>warn</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">If <code>TRUE</code>, warning messages are produced if commenting (or uncommenting) fails due to mispecifification
of <code>at</code>.</dd>
  <dt>...</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">Additional named arguments to <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code>, which are applicable if <code>at</code> is a character string.
In other words, <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/grep>grep</a></code> is used to search for the instances of <code>at</code>.</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Details</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">Some languages provide a way to comment multiple lines of code with a single pair of beginning and ending commenting
symbols.  However, <code>sed_comment</code> only adds/removes comment symbols to/from a single lines.
When comments are added by <code>sed_comment</code>, the comment symbols are placed at the beginning (and, if applicable, at the end) of
the selected lines. When comments are removed, the first instances of the beginning (and, if applicable, ending) comment symbols
are removed from the selected lines.</p>


  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">The new <code>stream</code> with the commented (or uncommented) lines. If the commenting fails because <code>at</code> is
specified incorrectly, <code>stream</code> is returned unchanged.</p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>######################################################################
# Let's create a stream to demonstrate the commenting symbol in each
# language
######################################################################
demoStream <- c("An R comment",
               "A C comment",
               "An html comment",
               "A tex comment",
               "A SAS comment",
               "A custom comment")

a <- sed_comment(demoStream, "R", type = "R")
a <- sed_comment(a, "C", type = "C")
a <- sed_comment(a, "html", type = "h")
a <- sed_comment(a, "tex", type = "t")
a <- sed_comment(a, "SAS", type = "S")
a <- sed_comment(a, "custom", type = c("&", ";"))

# Compare before and after
as.stream(demoStream)
a

######################################################################
# Various examples
######################################################################
aStream <- c("Here's a line to comment",
            "# A line to uncomment",
            "  <!-- Another commented line --> ",
            "And some comments * embedded in the line ;")
as.stream(aStream)

# Comment the first line in C style
stream <- sed_comment(aStream, "to comment", type = "C")

# Comment the first line with a custom style
a <- sed_comment(aStream, "to comment", type = c("&&", "##"))
a

# Remove the custom comments
a <- sed_comment(a, 1, add = FALSE, type = c("&&", "##"))
a

# Remove the R comment from the 2nd line
a <- sed_comment(a, 2, add = FALSE, type = "R")
a

# Remove the html comments
a <- sed_comment(a, "Another", add = FALSE, type = "html")
a

# Remove the SAS comments
sed_comment(a, "embedded", add = FALSE, type = "SAS")

# Comment every line in Java style
b <- sed_comment(aStream, "comment", type = "Java")
b

# Remove the Java comments from the second and fourth lines
sed_comment(b, c(2, 4), add = FALSE, type = "Java")</code></pre>

<h4>See also</h4>

<code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, <code><a href=#streamedit>streamEdit</a></code>

# Hi-level wrapper



## streamEdit

<h3>High-level wrapper for stream editing functions</h3>

<p class="rd-p">High-level wrapper for stream editing functions (<code><a href='sed_insert.html'>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href='sed_replace.html'>sed_replace</a></code>,
<code><a href='sed_substitute.html'>sed_substitute</a></code>, and <code><a href='sed_comment.html'>sed_comment</a></code>) to execute any number of sequential
insertion, replacement, substitution, or commenting steps.</p>

<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>streamEdit(commandList, stream = NULL, inFile = NULL, outFile = NULL,
  warn = FALSE)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>commandList</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A list that designates the insertion, replacement, substitution, or commenting commands
that will be performed on <code>stream</code> (or the stream obtained from <code>inFile</code>).
The list must have names corresponding to unique abbreviations of
"insert", "replace", "substitute", and/or "comment".  Each element in <code>commandList</code> must also be
a list with names and values that correspond to the arguments of <code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>,
<code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, and/or <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code> respectively.  See Examples.</dd>
  <dt>stream</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character vector, each element typically (but not necessarily) containing the text
from a single line in a file, which can be generated via <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>.</dd>
  <dt>inFile</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string designating a file that is to be read (using <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/readLines>readLines</a></code>
and will become a <code>stream</code>,
where each line of the file is mapped to a single element in the character vector <code>stream</code>.</dd>
  <dt>outFile</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A character string designating a file to which the resulting, edited stream will be
written using <code><a href=http://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/topics/writeLines>writeLines</a></code>. If <code>outFile = NULL</code>, no file is written.</dd>
  <dt>warn</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">A logical that, when <code>TRUE</code>, issues a worning if the insertion, replacement, subsitution, or
commenting cannot be performed. See Details.</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Details</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">One (and only one) of <code>inFile</code> or <code>stream</code> must be specified.</p>

  <p class="rd-p">If <code>inFile</code> and <code>outFile</code> are the same, a backup copy of <code>inFile</code> is made by appending
"~" to the end of the filename, e.g., if the original file were &#145;<span class = "file">aFile.txt</span>&#146;, the backup would be
&#145;<span class = "file">aFile.txt~</span>&#146;.</p>

  <p class="rd-p">The value of <code>warn</code> in <code>streamEdit</code> is passed to the worker functions
(<code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, and <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code>)
unless the <code>warn</code> argument is specified for a command in <code>commandList</code>, in which case, for that
particular command, the locally supplied value of <code>warn</code> takes precedence.</p>


  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">Invisibly returns the edited stream, and writes the stream to a file if <code>outFile</code> is supplied.</p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>################################################################################
# Let's create an example stream we can edit
################################################################################
cat("Here's a line\n",
   "Line after which we'll insert a string\n",
   "A line we'll delete\n",
   "A line we'll replace with something else\n",
   "A line where we'll make a substitution\n",
   "A line we'll comment\n",
   "The last line\n",
   sep = "", file = "tmpTest_streamEdit.txt")

# Read the file into a 'stream'
s <- readLines("tmpTest_streamEdit.txt")

################################################################################
# Excecute a series of commands 'manually', using the individual worker functions
################################################################################

s <- sed_insert(s, after = 3, insertion = "Here's an insertion")
s <- sed_replace(s, at = "delete", replacement = NULL)
s <- sed_replace(s, at = "we'll replace", replacement = "The replacement", fixed = TRUE)
s <- sed_substitute(s, pattern = "make a substitution", replacement = "have a party")
s <- sed_comment(s, at = "comment", type = "html")
s

################################################################################
# Now execute these same commands using a single call to streamEdit(), along
# with reading the input file and writing the output file
################################################################################

# Build the list of commands
comList <- list(

 # i for 'insert', arguments for sed_insert()
 i = list(after = 3, insertion = "Here's an insertion"),

 # r for 'replace', arguments for sed_replace()
 r = list(at = "delete", replacement = NULL),

 # r for 'replace', arguments for sed_replace()
 r = list(at = "we'll replace", replacement = "The replacement", fixed = TRUE),

 # s for 'substitute', arguments for sed_substitute()
 s = list(pattern = "make a substitution", replacement = "have a party"),

 # c for 'comment', arguments for sed_comment()
 c = list(at = "comment", type = "html")

)

s1 <- streamEdit(comList, inFile = "tmpTest_streamEdit.txt",
                outFile = "tmpTest_streamEdit1.txt")
s1

# Compare the results
identical(s, s1)

# Remove the files
unlink(c("tmpTest_streamEdit.txt", "tmpTest_streamEdit1.txt"))</code></pre>

<h4>See also</h4>

<code><a href=#sed_insert>sed_insert</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_replace>sed_replace</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_substitute>sed_substitute</a></code>, <code><a href=#sed_comment>sed_comment</a></code>


<h4>Author</h4>

Landon Sego


# The 'stream' class and print method



## as.stream

<h3>Converts a character vector to an object of class "stream"</h3>


<h4>Usage</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>as.stream(obj)

printstream(x, ...)</code></pre>

<h4>Arguments</h4>
<dl class="rd-dl">
  <dt>obj</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">The character vector to be converted to a "stream" object</dd>
  <dt>x</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">The "stream" object to be printed.</dd>
  <dt>...</dt>
  <dd class="rd-dd">Ignored</dd>
</dl>

  <h4>Value</h4>

  <p class="rd-p">The same character vector, only it now inherits from class "stream"</p>


  <h4>Methods (by generic)</h4>

  <p class="rd-p"><ul>
<li> <code>print</code>: Prints an object of class "stream" by removing quotes from the strings and printing each element
of the character vector on its own line.
</li>
</ul></p>



<h4>Examples</h4>
<pre class="r"><code>aStream <- c("string1", "string2", "string3")
aStream

# Note how it prints after we convert it to a stream object:
as.stream(aStream)</code></pre>

<h4>Author</h4>

Landon Sego
